DIY Blockchain

Introduction

A blockchain is a transactional singleton machine with shared-state. That is a virtual computer with a shared data storage as well as an emulated and shared CPU called a virtual machine. The shared data storage as well as the shared virtual machine are the same on each particiant running this virtual computer - they are canonical.

A domainchain is a domain specific blockchain. An example for a domainchain is the Asset Management Computer.

A webchain is a blockchain that is executable in the browser. An example of a webchain is Nimiq

State

Traditional (Data): A technology consisting of computer components and recording media that are used to retain digital data. Modern (State) Shared data stored in a mapping.

The storage or State has two main goals

  • lower disk storage footprint
  • allow for efficient/light state transition proofs (performance).

Validity

Traditional (CPU): The central processing unit (CPU) of a computer is what manipulates data by performing computations. Modern (VM) In our case the CPU is virtual (software rather than hardware) and emulated using the hardware CPU. This is called a Virtual Machine (VM).

The Virtual Machine is the execution environment that can modify the Melon chain state. Modifications happen according to the Melon state transistion function.

Canonicality

Modern (One truth): A new concept, native to blockchain technology. Establishes one truth among many possiblities.
